text: Beyond the long-term IV, you can actually extract the market's view of IV crush for $MSFT by analyzing the volatility surface. This is one of the things we offer in our Quantcha Option Ratings data available through Nasdaq: https://data.nasdaq.com/data/QOR-us-equity-option-ratings

One way to ballpark the expected earnings IV crush for stocks like $MSFT is to compare them with the long-term IV. However, IV tends to immediately crush well below the long-term numbers. 
 
https://quantcha.com/news/an-analysis-of-trading-earnings-releases-using-options/

One of the reasons long options don't usually do well for earnings trades is due to the crush that hits implied volatility (IV), and it's no different for $MSFT. The ATM earnings IV never retained more than 57% after the release. 
 
https://quantcha.com/news/an-analysis-of-trading-earnings-releases-using-options/

Removing liquidity issues by using midpoint pricing for $MSFT earnings shows better returns (unsurprisingly), but the naked long trades still don't keep pace with the underlying. 
 
https://quantcha.com/news/an-analysis-of-trading-earnings-releases-using-options/

Directionally trading $MSFT earnings with long options hasn't been a winning strategy based on market pricing. The only single-leg trade that produced an average gain was selling puts. This is partially due to most reports coming during a bull run. 
https://quantcha.com/news/an-analysis-of-trading-earnings-releases-using-options/

Studying the most recent 25 $MSFT earnings, we can see that options have been priced really accurately. The magnitude of the average move was just 0.05% off from what the options had priced. 
https://quantcha.com/news/an-analysis-of-trading-earnings-releases-using-options/
$MSFT rejected 315  spot https://youtu.be/AEFTnxuzL-Q

A deep dive into trading options with earnings. But it goes beyond simple strategies and discusses some of the important financial concepts underpinning IV and IV crush around earnings. While the focus is on $MSFT, there is broader market coverage as well.

We've just published our latest research report on trading earnings with options. In it we explore the performance of directional and volatility trading, as well as the impact of earnings IV crush, especially for $MSFT. https://quantcha.com/news/quantchas-latest-research-report-on-trading-earnings-with-options-now-available/
